Status: Approved in the EU.[9] Approved in the US.[10]

Status: Restricted use approved in the EU.[9][12]

Name: Fast Yellow AB
Status: Forbidden in the EU and US.[13]

Name: Sunset Yellow FCF

Name: Cochineal
Status: Approved in the EU.[9] Approved in the US.[10]

Name: Citrus Red 2
Status: Approved in the United States only for use in colouring the skin of oranges.[15]

Name: Carmoisine
Status: Approved in the EU.[9] Undergoing a voluntary phase-out in the UK. Currently banned in Canada, Japan, Norway, USA [citation needed] EU currently evaluating health risks.[citation needed]

Name: Amaranth
Status: Approved in the EU.[9] Banned in the United States.[16]

Name: Ponceau 4R
Status: Restricted use approved in the EU.[9][12]

Name: Ponceau SX
Status: Only permitted for externally applied drugs and cosmetics in the US.[17][18][19]

Name: Erythrosine
Status: Approved in the EU.[9] Banned in the US.[20]

Name: Allura Red AC
Status: Approved in the EU,[9] but banned by individual EU member states: Austria, Belgium, Denmark, France, Germany, and Sweden. Also banned by non-EU countries Norway and Switzerland.[21] Undergoing a voluntary phase out in the UK. Approved in the US.[10]

Name: Patent Blue V
Status: Approved in the EU.[9] Banned in the US and Australia.[citation needed]

Name: Indigo carmine
Status: Approved in the EU.[9] Approved in the US.[10]

Status: Approved in the EU.[9] Approved in the US.[10]

Name: Iron oxides and iron hydroxides
Status: Approved in the EU.[9] Approved in the US for sausage casings.[10]

Name: Potassium nitrite
Status: Approved in the EU.[9] In April 2023 the French Court of Appeals of Limoges confirmed that food-watch NGO Yuka was legally legitimate in describing Potassium Nitrite "and other nitrates" E249 to E252 as a "cancer risk", and thus rejected an appeal by the French charcuterie industry against the organisation.[25]

Status: Approved in Australia and New Zealand[27]
